ÐŸÐ¾Ð³Ð°ÑÐ¸Ñ‚ÑŒ ÐºÑ€ÐµÐ´Ð¸Ñ‚ ÑÐ¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð² Ñ‚ÐµÑ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ð¸ 3 Ð¼ÐµÑÑÑ†ÐµÐ².

loan.use: Buying flour

loan.name: Phan

texts.en: Mrs. Phan H. is a villager in Pouthi Reamea Village in Kandal Province. She is a pig breeder who raises four pigs. She now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to purchase pig food to feed them. Thus, Mrs. Phan H. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Pring Chhorn, helps his wife in her business. Mrs. Phan H. is 39 years old and the mother of three children who are all attending school. Mrs. Phan H. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loan.use: To purchase pig food to feed four pigs.

loan.name: Sugran M.ameen's Group

texts.en:
Sugran baji is a wife of M. and lives in a small city named Kasur, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the last 25 years. She is the mother of four children: one daughter and three sons. Her elder son makes embroidered dresses. The next eldest to him has a lathe job. Her husband is a teacher and teaches the students about Islam (Muslim religion). Sugran baji is a hardworking lady, and she teaches her children to be hard workers. She is a housewife but she has a thread-making business. She buys sweaters and removes the threads from them. After washing it, she sells the thread in the market and earns a profit. She successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy material (thread, cloth) for her elder son who is in the decorative embroidery profession.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Khursheed baji wants a loan to buy a lathe machine. Nazia baji wants a loan to material (lentils, cooking oil, rice) for her grocery shop. Parveen baji and Naziran baji each want a loan to buy supplies (chair, mirror) for her beauty salon. Zareena M. wants a loan to buy material (thread, cloth) for her embroidery business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy material for embroidery business

loan.name: Srean

texts.en: Mrs. Srean T. lives in Preak Ta Ker Village in Kandal Province. She is a secondhand clothes seller. She is a 44-year-old widow with five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the others are attending high school. Mrs. Srean T. and her oldest daughter are breadwinners who can make a small income to support the family. In order to improve her living conditions, Mrs. Srean T. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her household.

loan.use: To build a new house

loan.name: Mariam Kakoozaâ€™S Group

texts.en:
Mariam has been operating this business for the last 4 years. She works six days a week and operates a salon and beauty shop. She buys her merchandise twice a week from the Kampala city centre and uses public transport back to her shop. Mariam rents the shop where she operates her business and sells on both a retail and wholesale basis. Her customers are women in her community and those on the move. She works on 3-4 customers daily. Her challenges include: high rental charges, transport costs, thieves who usually break into her shop, and flooding during the rainy season. The area where she is operating is prone to floods, and this destroys her merchandise.

She was inspired to join MCDT because it was dealing with the active poor. She caters to customers who were previously moving long distances looking for salons and cosmetics. She has been with MCDT for the last 3 years and is servicing her seventh loan. She has been able to improve her standards of living by getting three meals daily and also taking her children to good schools. Her main inspiration is owning a permanent commercial house where she will be operating and also seeing her business progressing.

Mariam is a leader of a 5-member group. She is 38 years old and married with 5 children. They are aged between 18 and 10 years, and they are all in school. Mariam owns a five-room house in which she lives with 7 people. She also takes care of two orphans of her late brother. There is no piped water, but she has electricity. She resides and works in a semi-urban and slum area in the outskirts of Kampala.

loan.use: To invest in her inventory

loan.name: Doem

texts.en: Mr. Doem C. is a bread seller in Preak Pe Village in Kandal Province. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it. He is requesting a loan to buy more buns to resell them. His wife, Mrs. Kuy Touch, assists her husband's business. Mr. Doem C. is 54 years old and the father of four children who are all attending junior high school. His wife is on the right of the photo.

loan.use: To buy more buns to resell them

loan.name: Azizan's Group

texts.en:
Azizan baji is a wife of M. and lives in a small city named Kasur, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the last 30 years. Azizan baji is the mother of seven children: four sons and three daughters. Her husband makes cloth from his power loom machines and sells them in the market and earns a good profit. Azizan baji is a housewife and also sells thread to different areas. She owes a two-room brick house. She successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy oil to save their power looms machine from rust.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Tasleem baji, Bushra baji, and Hajira baji each want a loan to buy thread to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy oil for a machine

loan.name: Sruy

texts.en:
This is the second time for Mrs. Sruy I. to take a loan in order to improve her living conditions. She is a farmer who cultivates twice a year in the field which located in Pro Theat Village in Kandal Province. Although Mrs. Sruy I. tries to cultivate twice a year, she still has a little revenue, so she now wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Sruy I. decided to ask for a loan to buy a piece of land in order to cultivate rice and vegetables. Her husband, Mr. Yoen ThI., is a laborer who can make a small income to support his family.

Mrs. Sruy I. is 38 years old and the mother of five children. One of her children is employed in a garment factory while three more are attending school. The remaining one is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown in the picture because Mrs. Sruy I. is very busy with her work.

loan.use: To buy a piece of land in order to cultivate rice and vegetables

loan.name: Kutfiya

texts.ru:
Kutfiya H. lives in area Jalollidini Rumi. She is a widow with two children. Despite her difficult situation, being single with two children, Kutfiya began working. She works in business. She sells vegetables and fruit in a market. She has been doing this for two years. She plans to increase her sales by selling potatoes wholesale in the season when people are stockpiling them. If she sells her product wholesale, she can make good money and pay off her loan in 3 months.

Translated from Russian by Melissa, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.use: Increase sales

loan.name: Beatrice Musisiâ€˜S Group

texts.en:
Beatrice works five days a week and operates a salon. She buys her merchandise from Kampala city centre. She buys all types of goods from both retail and wholesale and uses public transport to transport her merchandise from Kampala to her salon/shop in Bwaise. She makes the trip twice a week. Her customers are women in her community and those on the move.

Her challenges include paying high taxes, high rental charges, and transport costs. Flooding is a problem during the rainy season as the area where she is operating is prone to floods, which destroys her merchandise. It was once a wetland. Another challenge is that of her business being seasonal. During periods when there is low demand for salons, she switches to selling cereals and legumes, mainly dried beans. She has been operating this business for the last 10 years and was inspired by the way women were moving long distances looking for salons. She has been able to improve her standards of living, provide her family with three meals daily. Her main inspiration is owning a permanent home to operate from and also seeing her business progressing.

Beatrice is the leader of a 4-member group. She is 28 years old and married with 2 children. They are 7 and 2 years old. The one aged seven years is in school. She rents a three-room house in which she lives with 5 people. There is no piped water and electricity. She resides and works in a semi-urban and slum area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala.

loan.use: To purchase more beans

loan.name: Oum

texts.en: This the second time for Mrs. Oum N. to ask for a loan in order to improve her standard of living. She sells lottery in Preak Thom Village in Kandal Province. She is a 44-year-old widow with three children. One of her children is a worker in a Chinese noodle restaurant, while anther one owns a small grocery store in the local village. The youngest one assists Mrs. Oum N. with her business. In order to improve her living conditions, Mrs. Oum N. wants to start a pig-breeding business. She decided to ask for a loan to buy ten piglets for breeding and reselling later at a better price.

loan.use: To buy ten piglets for breeding

loan.name: Les Lingueres De Falokh Group

texts.fr:
Through the loans obtained over the past two years from the UIMCEC organization, the women of this group are now shining examples. Each of them has organized her own retail business, where the residents of the area come to resupply themselves with basic need goods. With the income drawn from their businesses, they are able to pay for the medical and educational costs of their children and parents.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

A travers les prets obtenus depuis deux (02) ans au prÃ©s de l U-IMCEC,les femmes de ce groupement sont aujourd'hui des exemples .chacune d 'entre elle a montÃ© son propre commerce de dÃ©tail ou les habitants du quartier viennent se ravitailler en produits de prmieres nÃ©cessites. loan.name: Najma's Group

texts.en:
Najma baji is a wife of N. A. and lives in a small city named Kasur, Pakistan. She has been living in this city with her family for the last 22 years. Her house is based in one room where she and two more family members live. Najma baji is a housewife but she makes thread and sells it in market to earn profit. Her husband has an electronics shop. Najma baji has one son, and he is 16 years old. She successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy electronic supplies (washing machines, stoves) to expand her husbandâ€™s business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Allah Rakhi baji and Sugran baji each want a loan to buy thread to resell. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy embroidery material (thread, cloth, and needles).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To buy electrical goods

This business seasonal, therefore he plans to takeout a loan for 3 months. It will help him make good money. He has two years of experience in this field. Hotam lives with his family. He is married and has five children.

loan.name: Elishikaria's Fadhili Group

texts.en:
Elishikaria is 31 years old. She is married with 3 children aged 12, 8, and 4 years old. She is a farmer and milk seller since 2003. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Elishikaria now hopes for a loan to buy more farm equipment and milk for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Tasimbora and Elishiwaria, who have businesses dealing with chicken and milk sales and banana and eggs sale.

loan.use: To expand her business.

loan.name: Rebeca

texts.en:
Rebeca is married with 5 children ages 19, 15, 5, 3, and 1. She has been a vegetable seller since 1998. Every day, she works from 8am to 12pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Rebeca now hopes for a loan to buy more vegetables for her business.

They have benefited from two previous loans, which they repaid without incident. It is with the goal of increasing their stock that they are asking for this new loan.

Witnes now hopes for a loan to buy more bananas and maize for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Anastazia , who has a business dealing with grocery ownership.

loan.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is 40 years old. She is married with one child aged 6 years old. She has been running a small shop since 2002. Every day, she works from 6am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Eunice now hopes for a loan to buy more products for her business.

loan.name: Rebeca

texts.en:
Rebeca is 26 years old. She is married with 2 children. She also takes care of 2 other children aged 13 and 10 years old. She has been a maize seller since 2005. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Rebeca now hopes for a loan to buy more maize for re-sale.

loan.use: To buy more maize for resale

loan.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is 41 years old. She is married with 3 children aged 18, 15, and 10 years old. She has been a banana seller since 2004. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Anna now hopes for a loan to buy more bananas for her business.

loan.use: To buy more bananas for her business

loan.name: Ndefisiwa

texts.en:
Ndefisiwa is married with 3 children aged 17, 15, and 10. She also takes care of 2 other children. She has been a beans seller since 1999. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Ndefisiwa now hopes for a loan to buy more beans for resale.

loan.use: To buy more beans for re-sale

loan.name: Ndetomariswa

texts.en:
Ndetomariswa is 49 years old. She is married with 2 children aged 18 and 14 years old. She is a milk and banana seller since 2005. Every day, she works from 10am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $135 from her sales.

Ndetomariswa now hopes for a loan to buy more milk and bananas for her business.

Helena now hopes for a loan to buy more milk and maize for re-sale.

texts.en:
Janeth is 28 years old. She is married with 2 children aged 10 and 5 years old. She has been running a small shop since 2005. Every day, she works from 7am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Maria now hopes for a loan to buy more products for her business.

Naisiligaki now hopes for a loan to buy more tomatoes and vegetables for her business.

loan.use: To buy more tomatoes and vegetables for her business

loan.name: Khady

texts.fr:
Khady A. was born in 1966 in Thies. She is married and has one daughter. She lives in the Keur Ablaye Yakhine area with her husband. She has been commercially active for more than 15 years, with the help of her husband. Her business consists of buying merchandise in bulk, which she re-sells to retailers. With the coming of Ramadan, she is asking for this loan to increase her stock.

loan.name: Ameth

texts.fr:
Mr. Ameth T. is a young unmarried man born on 15 May 1981 in Thies. He has been a member of the UIMCEC loan program for three years, and is a hairdresser by profession. He repaid two previous loans without incident. He is asking for this loan with the goal of supplying himself with hairstyling equipment and improving his salon.

loan.use: To buy hairstyling equipment and redo his salon

loan.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Rehema S. is a twenty-eight-year-old married woman from Dar es Salaam. Rehema owns and operates a small stall, which she established six months ago, from which she sells roasted fish. She buys fresh fish daily from local fishermen as they come in with their morning catch. Rehema roasts and sells these fish either in the fish market or along the roads of Dar. Given its location along the Indian Ocean, fish is plentiful in the waters around Dar es Salaam and is a staple of the local Tanzanian diet. Rehema is an enterprising micro-entrepreneur who is taking advantage of a local need to make monthly profits of 120 USD. She is currently requesting a loan of 225 USD in order to purchase fish in larger quantities. In the future, Rehema plans to open another stall to sell her delectable treats.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy additional supplies of fish in bulk

loan.name: Boubou

texts.fr:
Boubou F. is a vulcanizer by trade who was born in 1974 in Ndary. He has a workshop in the Som quarter of ThiÃ¨s where he runs his business with his brother. He is requesting this loan so he can increase his supply of tires and stock up on motor vehicle oil.

boubou F. est un vulganisateur de profession nÃ© en 1974 Ã  ndary .il a un atelier au quartier som de thies oui il mÃ¨ne ses activitÃ©s avec son frÃ¨re.il demande ce pret en vue de renforcer son stock de pneus et de s'approvisioner en huile pour les moteurs de vÃ©hicule.

loan.name: Nessy

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Nessy N. is thirty-two years old. She is married with a two-year-old child. She also takes care of two other dependents who live with her because they attend school in the area. Earlier this year, Nessy opened a small shop from which she sells African traditional cloth. Local Tanzanian women purchase cloth from Nessyâ€™s shop and use it to make vitenge, the traditional dress worn by Tanzanian women. Nessy runs the store with one employee and earns about 100 USD in profit each month. Nessy is requesting a loan of 275 USD in order to purchase additional stock of African traditional cloth in bulk. Nessy expects to earn about 200 USD from increased sales after getting this loan. In the future she hopes to increase the quantity and range of the business.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To purchase additional stocks of traditional African cloth in bulk.

loan.name: Moussa

texts.fr:
Moussa N. is a young disabled man who was born in 1982 in ThiÃ¨s. After abandoning his studies, he decided to start selling spare parts so he would not have to resort to begging. He is requesting this loan so he can increase his supply of parts.

loan.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with a teenage son. She lives in Melitopol with her family and runs her business selling menâ€™s clothing in the central market. She launched her enterprise 9 years ago. Presently, she already has about $4000 in merchandise. Her turnover capital is about $1800. Her net profit amounts to $800.

Irina has rich experience working in this business. The first time she applied for Nadiya Ukraine financial assistance was 6 years ago. Ever since, her business has expanded, and she gained a reputation as an entrepreneur of integrity and great potential. Irina has consistent credit history in Nadiya Ukraine. We believe her positive standing and strong determination to achieve even higher goals will help her succeed and repay her loan on time.

loan.use: To increase her working capital

loan.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth M. is a married woman. She resides in the Temeke District in Dar es Salaam. She has a poultry business. She keeps both layers and broilers. It takes almost six months for layers to get the first harvest, while broilers take three years. She meets the daily demands of her family with her business. Her plan is to expand the business to increase sales. She needs a loan of $900 to meet her goals.

loan.use: To expand the business

loan.name: Selina

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Selina Y. is thirty years old and is married with two children aged four and 11. She also supports an additional dependent who lives with her because this young girlâ€™s parents cannot take care of her. Selina owns a shop where she sells rice, sugar, beans, wheat flour and maize flour. She is assisted by her husband and an employee in running her business. Selina earns about 600 USD from this business monthly. Selina is requesting a loan of 525 USD in order to purchase additional stocks of rice, sugar, beans and wheat flour. In the future, Selina plans to open another business.

loan.use: To purchase supplies in bulk for her store

loan.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is divorced with two daughters and a son. She is an entrepreneur from Melitopol where she sells leather goods in the central city market. She has been in this business for 10 years. Currently, Irina has about $2000 in inventory. Her net profit amounts to $600 a month.

Irina has been using Nadiya Ukraine's lending services for about 7 years. This time she is seeking a 5000 Grivna loan to purchase additional merchandise, increase her assortment of inventory, and generate additional income. We believe her ability to run the financial end of the enterprise and handle stress well will secure prompt loan repayment and consistent development of Irinaâ€™s enterprise.

loan.use: To increase her stock

loan.name: Abdoulaye

texts.fr:
Abdoulaye N. is a merchant by trade with five years experience. He is single and lives in the RandoulÃ¨ne Sud quarter. With Ramadan approaching, he is requesting this loan so he can increase his amount of stock.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

abdoulaye N. est un commerÃ§ant de profession qui a une expÃ©rience de cinq ans dans ce secteur d'activitÃ© .il est cÃ©libataire et vit au quartier randoulÃ¨ne sud. avec l'approche du ramadan ,il sollicite ce pret dans le but de renforcer ses stocks.

loan.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana has two grown children. She started working as a market vendor 6 years ago. Today she runs her own business selling menâ€™s suits in the central city market. Presently, Svetlana has about $4000 of working capital. Her monthly profit amounts to $600.

There are very few other businesses selling similar items in the market where Svetlana has her kiosk. Because of this, customer demand continues to grow all the time. Svetlana has established a reputation as an entrepreneur of integrity. She has repaid every loan she has received from Nadiya Ukraine without any defaults. Svetlana is requesting a loan for 3000 Grivnas to re-stock her inventory before the fall season. Compelling prices and a wide range of fashion choices to suit every taste and lifestyle will attract many new male clients to Svetlanaâ€™s business. An increase in sales will help her generate more profit and develop her trade even more.

loan.use: To increase her stock

loan.name: Latifa

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Latifa R. was born thirty-five years ago; she's married with two children, ages 10 and 16. In 2005, Latifa established her poultry business (kuku) which enables her to earn a monthly profit of 500 USD. Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. Who or what are "kuku," you may ask. Kuku means "chickens" in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. They require little start-up capital: you can start with two and wait for them to multiply naturally! They also require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Latifa is requesting the loan of 875 USD in order to purchase 400 chicks and additional feed. In the future, Latifa plans to buy even more chicks and expand her business further!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy additional chicks and feed for her poultry business.

loan.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Magdalena M. is twenty-seven years old. She is married with two children, ages one and five. She also has an additional dependent who lives with her because he is an orphan. In 2004, Magdalena established a business selling traditional African cloth that is used by local women to fashion their traditional outifts, called "vitenge." Magdalena runs her shop with the assistance of one employee and earns monthly profits of 400 USD. She is requesting a loan of 875 USD in order to purchase additional cloth and dye to manufacture this African traditional cloth. In the future, she hopes to make enough profit to open another business.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy cloth in bulk for her business

loan.name: Sifa

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Sifa J. is from Dar es Salaam. She is married and has three children between the ages of four and 12. Sifa has been running a Mama Lishe or local cafÃ© since 2005, from which she earns a monthly profit of 500 USD. Sifa is assisted by one employee and her husband in running the business. When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is "restaurant" or "cafÃ©," you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or cafÃ© in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places donâ€™t even appear in the Lonely Planetâ€™s budget guide, but if youâ€™re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces. Sifa is requesting a loan of 275 USD in order to purchase additional stocks of rice, sugar, maize flour, wheat flour and cooking oil.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy additional supplies for her cafe

loan.name: Rosmeri

texts.es:
Rosmeri is 29 years old and lives with her sister L., who dedicates herself to selling ceramic. Currently, Rosmeri is a seamstress who makes clothes using a knitting machine. She has always liked to work, and has been doing it for two years. She has a knitting machine in her home, which she uses to make hats, sweaters, pants, etc. She offers her goods for sale at the markets in the city of Juliaca. Her work is very well-received among the areaâ€™s residents. What she enjoys most is her knitting, an art sheâ€™s been inclined toward since she was a young girl. The most difficult aspect of her work is finishing her clothing on time, given that many of the items require a great deal of effort and she works alone. Rosmeri would like to start a family, for whom she wants to be able to offer a stable financial future.

With the money she is asking for, she will purchase more raw materials for making clothing and â€“ if possible â€“ another machine so someone can help her with her work. In the future, Rosmeri would like to have a small general store.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva volunteer.

Rosmeri tiene 29 aÃ±os, vive con su hermana L., quien se dedica a la venta de cerÃ¡mica. Actualmente, Rosmeri se dedica al tejido a mÃ¡quina de prendas de vestir, a ella siempre le ha gustado trabajar y lo viene haciendo desde hace ya doce aÃ±os atrÃ¡s.En su casa, ella posee una mÃ¡quina de tejer, en la cual elabora diferentes tipos de prendas entre gorritos, chompas, pantalones, etc. que ofrece en los mercados de la ciudad de Juliaca, los cuales tienen gran acogida dentro de la poblaciÃ³n.Lo que mÃ¡s le gusta de su trabajo es el tejer, ya que desde niÃ±a siempre tuvo inclinaciÃ³n ante este arte, lo mÃ¡s difÃ­cil de su trabajo es terminar a tiempo las prendas que venderÃ¡, ya que en muchos casos la elaboraciÃ³n demora un poco ya que lo hace sola. Rosmeri quiere formar una familia, a la cual poder ofrecerle un buen futuro econÃ³mico. Con el dinero que solicita comprara mÃ¡s materia prima para la producciÃ³n de sus prendas y si es posible otra mÃ¡quina, para que alguien la ayude en el trabajo, en el futuro Rosmeri quisiera tener una pequeÃ±a tienda de abarrotes.

loan.use: Purchase of raw materials (yarn) and another knitting machine.

loan.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! Gloria M. lives in Dar es Salaam where she owns a Mama Lishe (local cafe) that she established in 2004. She is assisted by three employees in the running of her cafÃ© and earns monthly profit of about 300 USD. When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is "restaurant" or "cafÃ©," you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or cafÃ© in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places donâ€™t even appear in the Lonely Planetâ€™s budget guide, but if youâ€™re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces. Gloria is requesting a loan of 800 USD in order to purchase a microwave and to make renovations to her cafÃ©. Gloria hopes that her larger cafÃ© will be able to hold more customers and thus enable her to expand her business and earn increased profits in the near future.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy additional supplies for her cafe

loan.name: Yanet Rosa

texts.es:
Yanet is 33 years old and a single mother who lives with her four children: Mery, who is 12, Yeni, 10 years old, Esther, 4 years of age, and Albino, who is only one. Yanet was born in the Pusi district, but has lived in the city of Juliaca for four years now. She did not finish her education given that she had to start work at a young age to help out her family financially. Yanet has dedicated herself to a number of occupations which is how, two years ago, she began selling clothing door-to-door throughout Juliaca. She enjoys this business because the clothing is much sought-after by local residents. The most difficult part is moving her merchandise around to sell. Thanks to God, she counts on the support of her children who are always close to help her with her daily sales which she carries out all day. Yanet had to help her children get ahead single-handedly, and wants to bring them better opportunities as they grow and become men and women. With the money from her loan, she thinks she will purchase more merchandise so she can in that way increase her income. In addition, she would like to open a clothing store so she can feel successful as a person and to provide a better quality of life for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva volunteer.

Yanet tiene 33 aÃ±os, es madre soltera, vive con sus cuatro hijos; Mery de 12, Yeni de 10, Esther de 4 y Albino de 1 aÃ±ito. Yanet naciÃ³ en el distrito de Pusi, pero reside en la ciudad de Juliaca hace 4 aÃ±os, no terminÃ³ sus estudios primarios debido a que se tuvo que trabajar para ayudar a su familia con la economÃ­a. Yanet se ha dedicado a trabajar en diferentes ocupaciones, es asÃ­, que hace dos aÃ±os se dedica a la venta de ropa de forma ambulatoria en la ciudad de Juliaca, gustÃ¡ndole este negocio ya que la ropa es muy solicitada por la gente, lo mÃ¡s difÃ­cil es tener que trasladar la mercaderÃ­a hasta el lugar de venta, gracias a Dios cuenta con el apoyo de sus hijos, los cuales siempre estÃ¡n cerca para ayudarla durante la venta que es todo el dÃ­a. Yanet tuvo que sacar adelante a sus cuatro hijos sola, ella quiere brindarles un mejor porvenir para que sean hombres y mujeres de provecho. Con el dinero del prÃ©stamo piensa adquirir mercaderÃ­a y asÃ­ poder mejorar sus ingresos econÃ³micos, ademÃ¡s desea abrir una tienda de ropa, para sentirse exitosa como persona y para brindarles a sus hijos una mejor calidad de vida.

loan.use: Purchase more merchandise to sell (clothing) and, later own, establish her own store.

loan.name: Josephene

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is thirty-eight-year-old Josephene M.. She is married with four children between the ages of two and 18. Josephene operates a stall from which she sells traditional African cloth; she opened the stall in 2006. Josephineâ€™s business sells a wide variety of colorful cloth with different patterns that Tanzanian women buy to fashion vitenge, their traditional outfit. The stall earns her about 100 USD per month in profits. Josephene is now requesting a loan of 875 USD to purchase large stocks of traditional African cloth in bulk. This will allow her to expand her customer base and thus earn increased profits. In the future, Josephene hopes to increase the quantity and range of cloth offered at her store even further.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy additional supplies of cloth in bulk

loan.name: Jessica Yeniz

texts.es:
Jessica is a member of the communal bank â€œAmor Divinoâ€.

Jessica is single and 29 years old. She studies communications sciences and, along with her mother, sells clothes and shoes which they offer to friends and family on credit. Jessica sells to her friends and schoolmates at the university, while her mother sells to her workmates. Her products are purchased in the city of Lima, which they visit on a monthly basis. In addition, Jessica works as an administrative assistant at the Magdalena parish.

Jessica needs a loan of 1,500 soles, funds that will be invested into the purchase of blouses, sweaters and pants.

Jessicaâ€™s dreams include wanting a stable business for her mother, having a store of her own, and getting her professional title.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva volunteer.

Jessica es soltera y tiene 29 aÃ±os, Jessica estudia ciencias de la comunicaciÃ³n, Jessica junto a su mama, venden ropa, calzados que ofrece a amigos, familiares, sus ventas son al crÃ©dito. Jessica vende a sus amigos, compaÃ±eras de universidad, mientras que su mama lo ofrece a sus compaÃ±eras de trabajo, sus productos son adquiridos en la ciudad de Lima a donde viajan mensualmente. AdemÃ¡s Jessica trabaja como personal administrativo en la parroquia de la Magdalena.

Jessica necesita un prÃ©stamo de 1500 soles, dinero que serÃ¡ invertido en la compra de blusas, chompas, pantalones.

Los sueÃ±os de Jessica son que su mamÃ¡ tenga un negocio estable, tener una tienda y sacar su titulo profesional.

loan.use: Jessica needs a loan of 1,500 soles, funds that will be invested into the purchase of blouses, sweaters and pants.

loan.name: Anatolia

texts.es:
Anatolia is a member of the communal bank â€œAmor Divinoâ€.

Anatolia is married, 43 years old and has six children. Anatolia sells natural medicines at the wholesale food market of the city of Ayacucho. Anatolia locates herself at the same spot each day from 5:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. She learned this activity from her husband who is a native of the Peruvian jungle. Anatolia travels to the central jungle on a monthly basis to purchase medicinal plants, tree resin and bark.

Anatolia needs a loan of 2,000 soles, funds that will be invested into the purchase of dry herbs, resin and rubber plant.

Anatolia dreams of having a home, a well-stocked store, making more sales and providing an education for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva volunteer.

Anatolia es conviviente, tiene 43 aÃ±os y 6 hijos, Anatolia vende medicinas naturales de manera ambulatoria en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad de Ayacucho, Anatolia se ubica diariamente en el mismo lugar a las 5 de la maÃ±ana hasta las 11 de la maÃ±ana, actividad que aprendiÃ³ de su esposo que es nativo de la selva peruana, Anatolia viaja mensualmente a la selva central a comprar plantas medicinales, resinas de Ã¡rboles, cortezas.

Anatolia necesita un prÃ©stamo de 2000 soles, dinero que serÃ¡ invertido en la compra de hierbas secas, resinas y palo de goma.

Anatolia sueÃ±a con tener una casa, una tienda surtida, vender por mayor y que sus hijos estudien.

loan.use: Anatolia needs a loan of 2,000 soles, funds that will be invested into the purchase of dry herbs, resin and rubber plant.

loan.name: Orfelinda, Alejandra Y Graciela Group

texts.es:
Orfelinda, Alejandra and GracieL. are members of the communal bank â€œAmor Divinoâ€.

Orfelinda is partnered, 43 years old and has three children. Orfelinda sells clothing that she offers to friends and relatives on credit. Orfelinda also makes cakes and chocolates, which she sells at wholesale to stores and she also takes orders.

Alejandra is married, 27 years old and has two children. Alejandra used to sell chickens and vegetables from a rented stand, but has had to leave the business due to the fact that her son is too small.

Meanwhile, GracieL. is married, 39 years old and has four children. GracieL. sells fish and trout in an ambulatory manner at the market of the city of Ayacucho and also door-to-door.

Orfelinda, Alejandra and GracieL. need a loan of 900 soles, 600 soles and 1,000 soles, funds that will be invested in the purchase of sweaters, jackets and trout. Alejandra will use the funds to make improvements to her home.

Orfelinda, Alejandra and GracieL. dream of having a bakery, a restaurant, traveling abroad to work, and having their own home.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva volunteer.

Orfelinda, Alejandra y GracieL. son socias del Banco Comunal Amor Divino.

Orfelinda es conviviente, tiene 43 aÃ±os y 3 hijos, Orfelinda venD. ropa que ofrece a amigos familiares, sus ventas son al crÃ©dito. AdemÃ¡s Orfelinda elabora tortas, chocolates que venD. por mayor a las tiendas y tambiÃ©n atienD. pedidos.

Por otro lado Alejandra es casada, tiene 27 aÃ±os y 2 hijos, Alejandra vendÃ­a pollos y verduras en un puesto alquilado y actualmente ha dejado D. realizar su negocio porque su hijo esta muy pequeÃ±o.

Mientras que GracieL. es casada, tiene 39 aÃ±os y 4 hijos, GracieL. venD. pescado y truchas D. manera ambulatoria en el mercado D. abastos D. L. ciudad D. Ayacucho y tambiÃ©n D. casa en casa.

loan.use: Orfelinda, Alejandra and Graciela need a loan of 900 soles, 600 soles, and 1,000 soles, funds that will be invested into the purchase of sweaters, jackets, and trout. Alejandra will use the funds to make improvements to her home.

loan.name: Felicia

texts.es:
Felicia is a member of the communal bank â€œUrpichaâ€, which means â€œlittle birdâ€ in Quechua.

Felicia is married, 35 years old, and has three children. Felicia lives in a rented house located on a busy street. Felicia has a store in her house where, along with her husbandâ€™s help, she sells groceries, vegetables, fruit, meats, ice creams, drinks and office supplies from 6:00 a.m. until 9:00 p.m. every day.

Felicia needs a loan of 1,000 soles, funds that will be invested into the purchase of rice and sugar.

Felicia dreams of running a well-stocked mini-mart, of owning her own home with all the necessary amenities, and of her children becoming professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva volunteer.

loan.name: Teofila

texts.es:
Teofila is a member of the communal bank â€œUrpichaâ€, which means â€œlittle birdâ€ in Quechua.

Teofila is married, 45 years old and has nine children of whom five still live with her. Teofila lives in a rustic home in the San JosÃ© neighborhood, a zone that was invaded a few years ago. Teofila has a small store where she sells groceries, vegetables, fruit, wood and drinks. Teofila also has laborers make clay bricks for her, which she also sells in her store. On Saturdays and Sundays she travels to the markets of the region where she sells her groceries and fruit. In turn, at those markets she buys cereals and cheeses which she sells in her neighborhood and in the markets in Ayacucho.

Teofila needs a loan of 1,000 soles, funds that will be invested into the purchase of wood and clay from which to make her bricks.

Teofila dreams of improving her business, expanding her store and having her own working capital.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva volunteer.

Teofila tiene una pequeÃ±a tienda en donde vende abarrotes, verduras, frutas, leÃ±a y bebidas. AdemÃ¡s Teofila manda elaborar adobes con peones, los cuales son vendidos en el mismo lugar. loan.name: Antonieta, Liliana Y TabiÃ±a Group

texts.es:
Antonieta, Liliana and TabiÃ±a are members of the communal bank â€œUrpichaâ€, which means â€œlittle birdâ€ in Quechua.

Antonieta is partnered, 25 years old and has one child. Antonieta sells canned condiments that she hand makes herself at home with the help of her brothers. She sells her products at wholesale from store-to-store.

Liliana is also partnered, 21 years old and has two children. Liliana sells â€œsalchipollosâ€ (a typical Peruvian food prepared with chicken and potatoes) in the afternoons on a busy street in her neighborhood.

In the meantime, TabiÃ±a is partnered, 20 years old and has a one daughter. TabiÃ±a sells wood from her parentsâ€™ home, which is where she lives.

Antonieta, Liliana and TabiÃ±a need loans of 600 soles, 600 soles, and 400 soles, funds that will be invested in the purchase of cinnamon, potatoes and wood.

Antonieta, Liliana and TabiÃ±aâ€™s dreams include building their own houses, having all the necessary comforts of home, providing a good education for their children, and having a restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva volunteer.

loan.name: Coura

texts.fr:
Mrs. Coura G. has been a restaurant owner for about ten years. She has a good reputation thanks to the quality of her meals.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Mme coura G. est restauratrice depuis une dizaine d'annee. Elle a une bonne reputation grace a la qualite de ses repas.

loan.use: Catering

loan.name: Yacine

texts.fr:
Yacine N. is a seamstress who was born in 1962 in Thies. She is married with three children and has opened her shop near the UIMCEC office in Thies. She has recruited two tailors who make womenâ€™s clothing and she is responsible for the sale of this clothing to her clients. In preparation for the religious holidays, she would like to increase her stock of cloth and sewing supplies.

Translated by Allana Carlyle, Kiva volunteer.

yacine N. est une couturiÃ¨re nÃ©e en 1962 Ã  thies .elle est mariÃ©e et mÃ¨re de trois enfants.elle a ouvert un atelier pres du bureau de UIMCEC DE THIES.elle a recrutÃ© deux tailleurs qui font de la confection d'habits de femmes et c'est elle qui est chargÃ©e de la revente Ã  ses clients .c'est dans le but de prÃ©parer les fetes religieuses qu'elle veut renforcer ses stocks de tissus et de fournitures de couture.

loan.use: The sale of ready-to-wear women's clothing

loan.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Mrs. Fatoumata S. is an experienced merchant who sells in-season fruits and vegetables. She is married and with the income she earns she helps her husband in providing for their family (the education of their children and medical bills). With this loan she hopes to increase her stock of fruits and vegetables to meet the demand of her clientele.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva volunteer.

Mme Fatoumata S. est une commercante experimentee dans son activite de vente de fruits et legumes en fonction des saisons. Elle est mariee et avec les revenus generes par son activite et elle aide son maridans la prise en charge des besoins familiaux (education des enfants et frais medicaux). Elle envisage avec le credit qu'elle sollicite de renforcer son stock de fruits et legumes pour mieux fideliser sa clientele.

loan.name: Dieyla

texts.fr:
Mrs. Dieyla N. earns a living selling vegetables with a quick turnover of stock. To satisfy a strong demand for her products, she is requesting a loan to increase her stock.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva volunteer.

Mme Dieyla N. exploite un commerce de legumes avec une forte rotation de stock . Pour satisfaire une forte demande , elle sollicite un credit pour renforcer son stock

loan.name: Les Lingueres De Falokh Serre Group

texts.fr:
Working together as a group named Â« Les Lingueres Â», these women, each whom is married with children, have started a business selling food products (rice, grains, milk, soap, peanut butter) to earn a living and to free themselves from the financial authority of their husbands. For two years they have been working with UIMCEC thanks to the various loans that they have been granted. The loans they obtain help strengthen the business income that they each earn by allowing them to purchase increased amounts of product to sell.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva volunteer.

loan.name: Diana Zoraida

texts.es:
Diana is 24 years old and lives with her husband and children. Each day she sells snacks to people from a corner near her house. A while ago she was able to get a small grill which was sufficient to prepare the kebabs she sells. In the morning, she usually goes to purchase the meat and then prepares the kebabs, and in the afternoons and evenings she sells them in the street. She's been doing this work for 3 years and she likes that she still has time to take care of her children.

6 months ago, she had to stop her work as she gave birth to her baby at only 7 months, and she needed to care for the baby's health. Now she is returning to her work as her baby has grown stronger. Even with the rough climate and cold days, she bundles up in a coat and continues her work. Her desire to take care of her children and improve their quality of life is her great motivation. Diana is requesting a loan to purchase more of the ingredients she needs to prepare the kebabs, such as meat and sausage. She would like to continue to grow her business and increase her income in the future.

Diana tiene 24 aÃ±os, vive con 3 de sus 4 hijos y con su esposo. Diariamente vende anticuchos (brochetas) en una esquina cercana a su casa, hace poco pudo adquirir una parrilla adecuada para su actividad. Por lo general, en las maÃ±anas va a comprar el corazÃ³n y las salchichas para la preparaciÃ³n, y sale por las tardes y noches a vender.Esto lo viene haciendo desde hace 3 aÃ±os, a ella le agrada esta actividad porque no requiere de todo su tiempo y puede atender a sus hijas, pero hace 6 meses ella dejÃ³ su trabajo porque dio a luz una bebe sietemesina y tuvo que cuidar de su salud, ahora volverÃ¡ a retomar su negocio porque su bebe ya se ha fortalecido.Una dificultad, pero que no la detiene, es el clima, algunos dÃ­as suelen ser muy frÃ­os, para ello Diana sale bien abrigada y con una pequeÃ±a carpa. Su esfuerza para tener mayores recursos para sostener a sus hijas y a futuro mejorar la infraestructura de su hogar. Diana solicita un prÃ©stamo para implementarse con palitos, carne y salchichas. Ella se ven el un futuro con un negocio mÃ¡s grande y con mejores ganancias.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loan.use: TO PURCHASE INGREDIENTS SUCH AS MEAT AND SAUSAGE FOR THE KEBABS SHE SELLS . SHE WOULD LIKE TO GROW HER SMALL BUSINESS AND INCREASE HER INCOME SO THAT SHE CAN CONTINUE TO TAKE CARE OF HER FAMILY.

loan.name: Auria Nancy

texts.es:
Auria is 46 years old and lives with her husband and their 4 children. She works selling various brands of beer from a small bar she runs. She's had the business for a year and a half, and she works at the bar all day. In addition to the bar, she also has a business where they provide computer services and copies. That shop is staffed with employees, so that Auria can run the bar. She knows that running the bar requires a great deal of responsibility, because you have to be careful about your customers when you sell alcohol. Most of her customers are workers, who come to have a chat with friends.

Auria works hard at these businesses so that she can pay for her children's education. She is requesting a loan to purchase beer in greater quantities so that her bar is better stocked and the business continues to grow.

Auria tiene 46 aÃ±os, actualmente vive con sus 4 hijos y su esposo. Su trabajo es la venta de cerveza de todas las marcas en un local que ha adecuado para ello. Viene haciendo esto cerca de un aÃ±o y medio, atiende en su bar casi todo el dÃ­a, paralelo a esto tiene un negocio de impresiones a computadora, contrata personal para esto, mientras ella se dedica enteramente a la atenciÃ³n de su bar.Auria sabe que se debe haber mucha responsabilidad en la vende de bebidas alcohÃ³licas, por lo cual es exigente en seleccionar a su clientela, que por lo general son personas que trabajan y vienen a su bar para poder charlar y beber de manera amistosa, cada cliente tiene un tiempo limitado para estar allÃ­ y de esa manera evita que se embriaguen. El esfuerzo de Auria se debe al sostenimiento de la educaciÃ³n para sus hijos. Solicita un prÃ©stamo para obtener mayor cantidad de cajas de cerveza, desea seguir adelante y poder mejorar las instalaciones de su bar.

loan.use: TO PURCHASE MORE BEER FOR THE SMALL BAR SHE RUNS, AND CONTINUE TO GROW HER BUSINESS WHICH PROVIDES INCOME FOR HER FAMILY.

loan.name: Celina Dalila

texts.es:
Celina is 22 years old and lives with her husband and their 9 year old son. After completing a program in cosmetology, she set up a small salon in her home. She runs the business every day, offering all kinds of hair cuts, color treatments, make up, etc. Her prices are fair and she offers good quality. The salon is now 2 years old thanks to a lot of hard work. This motivates Celina to work even harder and she likes her business, but her expenses are also growing as the business grows. Now there are new regulations from the city to file different papers. She is requesting the loan to purchase necessary items for her salon like a new hair dryer, as well as pay the necessary fees to the city so that she can operate her business

Celina tiene 32 aÃ±os, vive con su esposo y su hijo de 9 aÃ±os. Luego de prepararse en un centro de educaciÃ³n ocupacional en la especialidad de cosmetologÃ­a, ella decidiÃ³ instalar su fuente de ingreso en su casa, es asÃ­, que tiene su propio salÃ³n de belleza, donde atiende todos los dÃ­as, durante todo el dÃ­a, ofrece todo tipo de cortes de cabello, tintes, maquillaje, etc. sus precios son mÃ³dicos y su trabajo de calidad.El salÃ³n de Celina ya ha cumplido 2 aÃ±os de intensa labor, esto le anima a seguir adelante ya que le gusta mucho lo que hace, ademÃ¡s cada vez tiene mejores ingresos, ahora estÃ¡ en los todos los trÃ¡mites de regulaciÃ³n y permisos municipales para tener todos sus papeles en regla. Celina solicita este prÃ©stamo porque con ello implementarÃ¡ su salÃ³n, podrÃ¡ adquirir una nueva secadora de cabello y culminar el pago para el permiso municipal.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loan.use: TO PURCHASE A NEW HAIR DRYER FOR HER SALON, AS WELL AS PAY THE NEW FEES IMPOSED BY THE CITY TO RUN HER BUSINESS.

loan.name: Isabel Violeta

texts.es:
Isabel is 23 years old and lives with her brother and father. Half a year ago, she opened her phone shop realizing that there was an opportunity in her area for phone service as well as internet access. She runs her shop from Monday to Friday, resting on the weekends as she is pregnant. Her brother takes care of the shop on Saturdays and Sundays. isabel likes the business which allows her to take care of her family. As the baby's father is irresponsible, she will have to take care of her baby on her own. In the future she would like to open more locations for her business.

She is requesting a loan to purchase phone cards, as well as apply for the licensing she needs from her municipality.

Isabel tiene 23 aÃ±os, vive con su hermana y su padre, ella estÃ¡ actualmente embarazada. En sus enormes deseos de superaciÃ³n decide abrir su locutorio hace mas de medio aÃ±o, invirtiendo asÃ­, adecuadamente su capital, con buen ojo se percatÃ³ que ese servicio era lo que necesitaba su localidad.TambiÃ©n agregÃ³ cabinas de Internet, atiende de lunes a viernes, los fines de semana descansa dejando a su hermana en el cuidado y atenciÃ³n, Isabel estÃ¡ satisfecha de este trabajo que le permite el sustento de su familia y con el que podrÃ¡ mantener a su bebe, ya que se valdrÃ¡ sola, debido a la irresponsabilidad del que fue su pareja. En el futuro quiere tener varios establecimientos, y adicionalmente una botica. Isabel solicita un prÃ©stamo de 1000 soles, el cual invertirÃ¡ en la compra de tarjetas telefÃ³nicas, recargas virtuales y tambiÃ©n realizar el trÃ¡mite para la licencia de funcionamiento municipal.

loan.use: TO PURCHASE PHONE CARDS FOR HER BUSINESS, AS WELL AS PAY FOR THE APPLICATION TO OBTAIN A LICENSE FOR HER BUSINESS.

loan.name: Charita Mercedes

texts.es:
Charita is 33 years and lives with her 4 children and her elderly parents. She is a hardworking woman and for two years now she's worked selling grains and dried corn. Twice a week she travels to the jungle region to sell her merchandise in the city market. Once there, she can purchase fruit at wholesale prices and take it back with her to sell in her city of Huancayo. This work allows her to support her 4 children who all attend school. As she is separated from her husband, Charita has sole responsibility for her family's support

Her work becomes difficult during the rainy season, when she can't get to the places she needs to go to buy and sell her merchandise. If the roads are impassable, the fruit often goes bad before she can sell it. She is requesting this loan to invest in more stock and grow her business. She would like to be able to move her products by car or truck in the future, and sell them from her own small shop.

Charita tiene 33 aÃ±os, vive con sus 4 hijos y sus ancianos padres. Ella es una mujer de mucho esfuerzo, desde hace 2 aÃ±os se viene dedicando a la venta de granos; tales como habas y maÃ­z seco, viaja a la selva dos veces por semana para vender sus granos en el mercado de esa ciudad.AllÃ­ en la selva compra fruta al por mayor para venderla en su ciudad, Huancayo. De esta manera puede sostener a sus 4 hijos que estÃ¡n estudiando, ya que ella es el Ãºnico sostÃ©n que ellos tienen. Charita es separada de su esposo y sola corre con la economÃ­a de su hogar, por lo que cada dÃ­a trabaja con mucho empeÃ±o en su casa seleccionando los granos de que ha vender y de esa manera, tener lista la mercaderÃ­a para salir de viaje. Le agrada ver de cerca lo que puede comprar para luego vender, las dificultades se presentan cuando en la Ã©poca de lluvia, las carreteras se hacen inaccesibles, lo cual puede ocasionarle pÃ©rdidas y deterioro de la fruta. Solicita este prÃ©stamo para adquirir mÃ¡s mercaderÃ­a, que le permita mayores ganancias, ella se ve un futuro moviendo un gran capital y traer por camionadas sus productos para venderlos en un local exclusivo para ello.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loan.use: TO PURCHASE MORE STOCK TO HELP GROW HER BUSINESS SELLING GRAIN, DRIED CORN AND FRUIT.

loan.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
Maria Isabel lives in the 3-80 neighborhood of Managua. She runs a convenience store out of her home. She is married, and she also cares for her 78-year-old mother. The loans she is requesting will be used to build a room for her mother, because in to her advanced age she needs comfort and privacy. Maria Isabel has had her business for 12 years, starting out by selling caramels and beverages.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva volunteer

DoÃ±a Maria Isabel habita en el barrio 3-80 de Managua, en su casa de habitaciÃ³n tiene una pulperÃ­a la cual es atendida por ella misma. Es casada y a su cargo tiene a su madre de 78 aÃ±os de edad. El prÃ©stamo serÃ¡ usado para la construcciÃ³n de una habitaciÃ³n para su mamÃ¡, ya que por su avanzada edad, necesita de comodidad y privacidad. DoÃ±a Maria Isabel tiene 12 aÃ±os de tener su pequeÃ±o negocio el cual empezÃ³ con ventas de caramelos y refrescos.

loan.use: Build a room for her mother / ConstrucciÃ³n de un cuarto para su madre

loan.name: Hermes

texts.es:
Heremes is 37 years old and lives in the 3-80 neighborhood of Managua. He is married, and his wife takes care of the home and their two daughters, ages 6 and 8, during the day. Hermes is a taxi driver, and he also has rooms in his home that he rents out to different people. He has been driving taxis for 13 years, and hopes that within a short amount of time he'll be able to upgrade his cab for a newer model. The loan he is requesting will be used to remodel his tenants' rooms to provide them more services and make them feel more comfortable. With the money, he will purchase beams and zinc sheets to re-roof these rooms, since over time it has deteriorated.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva volunteer

Hermes tiene 37 aÃ±os de edad, habita en el barrio 3-80 de Managua, es casado, su esposa es ama de casa, tiene 2 hijas de 6 y 8 aÃ±os de edad. Hermes es taxista, y tambiÃ©n tiene un su vivienda habitaciones que alquila a diferentes personas. Tiene 13 aÃ±os de ser taxista y espera dentro de muy poco tiempo poder cambiar su unidad de taxi por una mÃ¡s nueva. El motivo del prÃ©stamo es para la remodelaciÃ³n de las habitaciones de sus inquilinos para asÃ­ darles un mejor servicio y que sus clientes se sientan mÃ¡s cÃ³modos. Con el dinero comprarÃ¡ perlines y zinc para cambirles el techo a estas habitaciones, ya que el paso del tiempo los ha deteriorado.

loan.use: Put up a new roof and beams over the rooms he rents / Cambiar techo y perlines de una habitaciÃ³n de alquiler

loan.name: Norma Y Maria Group

texts.es:
Norma is single, 34 years old and has 1 child. Norma sells food in the settlement of Yanama, she prepares breakfast and dinner. She is planning to open a new business; a grocery store.

On the other hand Maria is married, 47 years old and has 6 children. Every week Maria travels to the â€œAyacuchanaâ€ jungle where she sells vegetables and buys fruit to be sold at the market in the town of Ayacucho.

Norma and Maria need loans of 1500 and 600 soles respectively to be invested in the purchase of groceries, oranges and pineapples. Their dream is to educate their children as professionals, improve their businesses and build their houses.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Norma es soltera, tiene 34 aÃ±os y 1 hijo, Norma vende comida en el asentamiento humano de Yanama, prepara desayuno y cena, Norma tiene proyectado iniciar un nuevo negocio que es una tienda de abarrotes.

Mientras que Maria es casada, tiene 47 aÃ±os y 6 hijos, Maria viaja a la selva ayacuchana todas las semanas en donde vende verduras y de la selva compra frutas que vende en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Norma y Maria necesitan prestamos de 1500 soles, 600 soles, respectivamente, dinero que serÃ¡ invertido en la compra de abarrotes, naranja, piÃ±a. Los sueÃ±os de Norma y Maria son educar a sus hijos para que sean profesionales, mejorar sus negocios, construir su casa.

loan.use: Norma and Maria need loans of 1500 and 600 soles respectively to buy groceries, oranges and pineapples in order to increase sales.

loan.name: Felipa Del Socorro

texts.es:
L. is 36 years old, single and has no children. She lives in a small home built on her own efforts with plank walls and earthen floors. She is requesting a loan to tile her home and thus improve her living conditions. She works for AsunciÃ³n Hospital and the San RamÃ³n Clinic. In her home, she uses solar energy and when it's cloudy she doesn't turn on her lights, but she still is able to use electric appliances like her TV and speakers. She repaid her first loan before the allotted time and has an excellent credit history. She wants to improve her home because the rainy season has made it very muddy. Eventually, she hopes to put up concrete walls to add more security. Currently she is not concerned about a robbery because her mother lives next door, who takes care of it while she is at work.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva volunteer

La joven L., soltera con 36 aÃ±os de edad, sin hijos, habita en una casita pequeÃ±a construida por esfuerzo propio es de paredes de tabla, pizo de tierra, su crÃ©dito lo estÃ¡ solicitando para embaldozar y asi tener mejores condiciones, trabaja para el hospital AsunciÃ³n y la clÃ­nica San RamÃ³n, en su vivienda utiliza energÃ­a solar y cuando estÃ¡ nublado no encienden las lÃ¡mparas, pero sÃ­ sus aparatos elÃ©ctricos como T.V. y equipo de sonido. Esta seÃ±ora su primer crÃ©dito lo cancelÃ³ antes de la fecha establecida, presentando un excelente rÃ©cord crÃ©diticio, moral de pago y responsabilidad ante los compromisos asumidos, desea mejorar su vivienda porque en la Ã©poca lluviosa se le hace mucho lodo, posteriormente desea levantar las paredes de concreto, para dar mayor seguridad a su vivienda, en estos momentos no se le han presentado problemas de robo porque junto a su casita estÃ¡ la casa de su mamÃ¡, quien le cuida cuando ella estÃ¡ en su trabajo.

loan.use: Tile the floor of her home / Embaldozar piso de su vivienda

loan.name: Herminia

texts.es:
Herminia is a member of the Banco Comunal Las Alondras. She is married, 48 years old and has 4 children. Herminia lives in the District of San Juan Bautista. She sells meat at a stand located on the very popular market, F. Vivanco, in the center of the town of Ayacucho. Herminia, assisted by her husband and daughter, travels to the regional fairs three times a week to buy animals such as cattle, sheep, and pigs to be slaughtered at the townâ€™s slaughterhouse.

Herminia needs a loan of 1600 soles to be invested in buying pigs and sheep. It is her dream to place a roof on the second floor of her house, start a business for her daughter, and set up a grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Herminia es socia del Banco Comunal Las Alondras. Herminia es casada, tiene 48 aÃ±os y 4 hijos. Vive en el distrito D. San Juan Bautista donD. venD. carne en un puesto ubicado en el mercado F. Vivanco, un mercado con mucha concurrencia porque se ubica en el centro D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho. Herminia viaja a las ferias D. la regiÃ³n 3 veces por semana donD. compra animales como ganado vacuno, porcino, caprino, luego lo beneficia en el camal D. la ciudad. Actividad que realiza con la ayuda D. su esposo e hija.

Herminia necesita un prÃ©stamo D. 1600 soles, dinero que serÃ¡ invertido en la compra D. cerdos, carnero. Los sueÃ±os D. Herminia son techar el segundo piso D. su casa, implementar un negocio para su hija y tener una tienda D. abarrotes.

loan.use: Herminia needs a loan of 1600 soles to be invested in the purchase of cattle, pigs, and sheep.

loan.name: Fidelia Paola

texts.es:
Fidelia Paola is a grocery store clerk at the San Antonio Super. She is 34 years old, married with a 2 1/2 years old girl. She works from 8:00 a.m. until 8:00 p.m. Her niece takes care of her daughter and her only free day during the week is Tuesdays. She has been working for this business for 10 years. She is asking for her 6th loan to repair the floors of her sister's house where she lives and to repair the windows. In the future, she will build her home. She already has purchased the lot with the previous loans. Her husband helps her a little. Fidelia's wish is to be able to apply for a bigger loan in the future to start the construction of her house. She is a very responsible woman. Her previous five loans have been paid properly and on time. She is very satisfied for the courtesy and attention that the personnel of AFODENIC has given her

Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

Fidelia Paola trabajadora del SÃºper San Antonio, con 34 aÃ±os de edad, casada, con una niÃ±a de 2Â½ aÃ±os, ella trabaja de 8:00 am a 8:00 pm, su hija se la cuida una sobrina, el Ãºnico dÃ­a libre es el martes de cada semana, tiene 10 aÃ±os de laborar para este lugar. EstÃ¡ solicitando su 6to crÃ©dito el que utilizarÃ¡ para embaldozar el piso de la casa de su hermana que es donde ella habita y componer las ventanas, en el futuro construirÃ¡ su casa pues ya comprÃ³ el terreno con los crÃ©ditos anteriores; su esposo le ayuda un poco y su mayor ilusiÃ³n es en el futuro solicitar un crÃ©dito mayor para iniciar la construcciÃ³n de su vivienda. Es una joven muy responsable, sus 5 crÃ©ditos los ha cancelado en tiempo y forma, se siente satisfecha por la atenciÃ³n con que ha sido atendida por el personal de AFODENIC.

loan.use: Floor repairs and restoring the windows.

loan.name: Vilma

texts.es:
Vilma is a member of Banco Comunal Alondras. She has a partner, is 32 years old and has 1 daughter. She lives with her parents in the traditional neighborhood of Yaracc Yuracc. Together with her spouse she weaves handcrafted fabrics which she learned from her parents and she also has help from workers depending on the demand. She sells to intermediaries who sell to different department stores in the country. Vilma makes carpets, place mats, blankets or other products depending on orders.

Vilma needs a loan of 1600 soles to be invested in buying wool, thread and dye. It is Vilmaâ€™s dream to build her house, sell her fabrics directly to the department stores, and set up a stand at the handicrafts market of the town.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

Vilma es socia del Banco Comunal Alondras. Vilma es conviviente, tiene 32 aÃ±os y 1 hija, Vilma vive aun en la casa de sus padres ubicado en el barrio tradicional de Yuracc Yuracc, Vilma junto a su esposo realizan tejidos artesanales en telar, actividad que aprendiÃ³ de sus padres, Vilma cuenta ademÃ¡s con la ayuda de operarios, dependiendo de la demanda que tiene, sus ventas lo realiza a intermediarios que venden en diferentes departamentos del paÃ­s. Vilma produce, tapices, individuales, frazadas y otros productos dependiendo de los pedidos.

loan.use: Vilma needs a loan of 1600 soles to be invested in buying wool, thread, and dye.

loan.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia is a member of the Alondras Community Bank.

Julia is 39 years old and lives with her partner and 4 children. She travels to regional fairs where she purchases potatoes and grains which she later processes with a rented mill. Julia sells the final product in the San Felipe fair, where she goes every 15 days. While at the same fair, she purchases cheese which she sells for a profit to shopkeepers in Ayacucho.

Julia needs a 1,400 soles loan, which she will use to purchase grains and fruits. Julia's dream is to build and furnish her house, increase the size of her business and develop her own capital stock.

Translated from Spanish by Jordan Shanker, Kiva volunteer.

Julia es socia del Banco Comunal Alondras.

Julia es conviviente, tiene 39 aÃ±os y 4 hijos, Julia viaja a las ferias D. la regiÃ³n donD. compra papa, cereales que luego los procesa en un molino alquilado, estos productos los comercializa en la feria D. San Felipe a donD. viaja cada 15 dÃ­as, y D. la feria compra quesos que venD. por mayor a los comerciantes D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho y tambiÃ©n venD. en la selva ayacuchana a donD. viaja cada 15 dÃ­as.

Julia necesita un prÃ©stamo D. 1400 soles, dinero que serÃ¡ invertido en la compra D. cereales y frutas variadas. Los sueÃ±os D. Julia son construir su casa, amoblar su vivienda, ampliar su negocio y tener capital propio.

loan.use: Purchase grains and fruits.

loan.name: Haydee Berta

texts.es:
Haydee is a member of the communal bank called "Alondras."

Haydee is separated from her husband. She's 37 years old. She has 2 kids and one in the way. Haydee used to go to the city of Chincha every week to purchase eggs, but now that she's expecting she can no longer travel long distances. She gets the eggs delivered to her and she sells them by foot at the local supermarket in the city of Ayacucho.

Aside from that, she sells bread, which she purchases at wholesale price from local bakeries, and sells it every weekend with the help of her daughter.

Haydee would like to use this loan to purchase eggs. Haydee dreams to own a home, to continue to work and move ahead, and to own a car to lease and make more money.

Translated by a Kiva Volunteer.

Haydee es socia del Banco Comunal Alondras.

Haydee es separada, tiene 37 aÃ±os, 2 hijos y esta esperando a su tercer hijo, Haydee viajaba semanalmente a la ciudad de Chincha en donde compra huevos, pero debido a su estado ya no puede viajar y solamente le envÃ­an, sus ventas lo realiza ambulantemente en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

AdemÃ¡s Haydee los dÃ­as sÃ¡bados y domingos vende panes que compra de las panaderÃ­as por mayor, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su hija.

Haydee necesita un prÃ©stamo de 1500 soles dinero que serÃ¡ invertido en la compra de huevos. Haydee sueÃ±a con tener casa propia, seguir trabajando para salir adelante y tener un carro que le genere mayores ingresos.

loan.use: To purchase eggs

loan.name: Francisco JosÃ©

texts.es:
Mr. C. is a pharmaceutical sales executive. He is 40 years old and married to his wife, Marlene Amador. They have 5 children: 4 girls and 1 boy. Their eldest daughter studies at the high school, 2 go to elementary school, one of the girls goes to pre-school and the other is 2 years old and doesn't go to school yet. He has worked for Dicegsa Enterprises selling medicines for 9 years and traveling outside Juigalpa as part of his job . He is asking for his fourth loan which will be use to expand his home. It was constructed as part of a project and now it is too small for a family of 7. He will start the room construction because his children are growing and need independence. His wife is helping out a little since she elaborates bedding, mosquito nets, etc. She is a traveling salesperson and gets help from her father. She has worked at this job for 11 years and it has enable them to fulfill the household needs. Mr. C. is a client with an excellent credit record since he has paid the previous three loans in full and on time. He expresses that he will continue with the same disposition and ethic that he has shown before

Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer

El Sr. C. es ejecutivo de ventas de fÃ¡rmacos, casado con 40 aÃ±os de edad, su esposa Marlene Amador, con 5 hijos, 4 niÃ±as y un 1varÃ³n, su hija mayor estudia la secundaria, 2 cursan la primaria y una niÃ±a en pre-escolar, 1niÃ±a de 2 aÃ±os no estudia, trabaja para la empresa Dicegsa desde hace 9 aÃ±os, teniendo que salir fuera de Juigalpa a vender los medicamentos. EstÃ¡ solicitando su 4to. crÃ©dito el que utilizarÃ¡ para realizar ampliaciÃ³n de su vivienda, ya que Ã©sta fue construida por un proyecto y en estos momentos se hace muy pequeÃ±a para la familia de 7 personas. IniciarÃ¡ la construcciÃ³n de un cuarto ya que sus hijas e hijos estÃ¡n creciendo y necesita independencia. Su esposa le apoya un poco ya que se dedica a la elaboraciÃ³n de ropa de cama, mosquiteros, etc. ademÃ¡s es comerciante ambulante, su papÃ¡ le ayuda con la venta, tiene 11 aÃ±os de estar en el negocio, lo que les ha permitido cumplir con las necesidades del hogar. El seÃ±or C. es un cliente con un excelente rÃ©cord crÃ©diticio pues ha cancelado sus 3 crÃ©ditos anteriores en tiempo y forma, manifiesta que continuarÃ¡ con la misma disposiciÃ³n y moral de pago que ha presentado.
